options.label: B

questions.explanation:

These are more common in children and usually the middle of bone in affected. The first inoculation of the infection is lodged in centre of marrow cavity and is seen as spinal shaped extension of bone Treatment The mainstary is ATT. Rest to the part in functional position and starting early exercise is promoted. Amputation may be needed in cases of ankylosis of more than joint. Flexion abduction and external rotation A progressive pattern of destruction of the hip occurs in patients who are not treated. Treatment must be instituted early to salvage the hip. Total hip arthroplasty should be considered only after a safe period of absolute disease quiescence.

questions.correct_answer: C. Sequestrum is the radiolucent area seen in the area of chronic osteomyelitis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sequestrum is the radiolucent area seen in the area of chronic osteomyelitis Chronic osteomyelitis is the most typical complication of acute osteomyelitis. A chronic discharging sinus is the most typical presenting symptom. The lower end of the femur is the most typical site of chronic osteomyelitis. A key radiological feature is Sequestrum (a part of chronic osteomyelitis), which appears denser than surrounding normal bone because decalcification, which occurs in normal bones, does not happen The granulation tissue surrounding the sequestrum creates a radiolucent zone around it. A sequestrum may be visible in soft tissues. Involucrum is the dense sclerotic bone overlying a sequestrum. There may be some holes in the involucrum for the pus to drain out, and these holes are called cloacae. The bony cavities are lined by infected granulation tissue. Involucrum and cloacae are often visible.

questions.text: Most sensitive test for laboratory diagnosis of osteomyelitis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CRP Acute osteomyelitis Short duration, usually less than two weeks Symptoms include tenderness, limb, refusal to use the limb Fever and systemic symptoms variable Laboratory findings: • CRP—most sensitive test (increased in ≈97%) Most rapid rise and fall—a good measure of treatment success ESR—increased in approximately 90% CBC—WBCs increased in only a third Aspiration and biopsy cultures—most specific test Histopathology: bony spicules with live osteocytes surrounded by inflammatory cells Treatment: 6 weeks of antibiotics directed at specific organisms identified by culture

Highyeild:

Diagnosis can be made by the use of A. ESR- peak elevation occurs in 3-5 days, return to normal after 3 weeks of treatment started. CRP- Most reliable non invasive investigation for acute infection, reaches raises within 6 hrs of infection. It peaks in 2 days and return to normal in one week after treatment is started. B. Local Aspiration: Thick needle can be put in the bone for aspiration of pus. This is the best way to diagnose the infection and organism. C. Blood culture: It should ideally be sent before antibiotics started, usually positive in only 50% of cases D. Radiographs: Initially are negative; after 1 to 3 days can show soft tissue swelling and skeletal changes may take around 10-12 days to be visible on X-Rays. E. Ultrasonogram: USG can help in differentiating acute hematogenous osteomyelitis from cellulits, soft tissue abscess and acute septic arthritis. F. Bone scan: Three commonly used radio isotopes are Technetium: 99m scans can confirm diagnosis 24 to 48 hours after onset of disease Gallium and Indium scans can also be used. leukocytes differentiates osteomyelitis from reactive bone formation G. MRI: Can show inflammatory changes in bone marrow and soft tissues and it can reveal interosseous and subperiosteal collection

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. ESR is increased in approximately 90% of the cases Option: C. WBC increased in only a third of the cases Option: D. ASPIRATION AND CULTURE is the most specific test

Highyeild:

Causative organism: Mycobacterium T.B Etiology: B of the skeletal system is always secondary to primary focus like in lungs or lymph nodes. Route of spread may be hematogenous or from surrounding focus. Pott's spine Spine is the most common site of skeletal tuberculosis (followed by hip and knee) Any level of spine may be involved, the lower thoracic region being the most common, next in decreasing order of frequency are lumbar, upper dorsal cervical sacral region (dorsolumbar region (T11-L1) is the usually most commonly involved segment). Types of involvement of the spine Paradiscal: destruction of end plates with intervertebral disc involvement. This is the most common type of involvement. Pathology The involvement of contigous area of the adjaent vertebra causes destruction of the vertebra. This may causes two types of vertebral collapse Wedge collapse Concentric collapse The abscess so formed in tuberculosis is known as cold abscess and it has following features: It is due to exudative reaction There are no signs of inflammation It is composed of WBC, serum, caseous material, bone debris, tuberculosis bacilli Abscess of thoracic spine may rupture into mediastinum (bird's nest abscess) or may reach to anterior chest wall in parasternal area through intercostal vessels Other area of spread of abscess Cervical spine Para spinal region in back Post/Ant cervical triangles Along brachial plexus Along inter costal space Dorsal or Lumbar spine Iliac fossa (It's the psoas abscess which can be felt at iliac region) Lumbar triangle Below inguinal ligament May go upto knee If bilateral psoas abscess is there it can lead to bilateral hip flexion or pseudo hip flexion deformity of hip.

questions.text: Involvement of intervertebral disc is more suggestive of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carries spine Reduction of disc space: This is the earliest sign in the commoner, paradiscal type of tuberculosis. In the early stages, reduction in disc space may be minimal and detectable only by comparing the height of the suspected disc with those above and below it. In advanced stages, disc space may be completely lost. A lateral X-ray is better for the evaluation of disc space. Reduction of disc space is an essential sign because in other diseases of the spine, e.g., secondaries in the spine, the disc space is well preserved.

Highyeild:

Paradiscal is the most common type as the vertebra develops from the sclerotome which lie on either side of the Notochord. The lower half of upper vertebra and upper half of lower vertebra with intervening disc have same blood supply and therefore, the most common route of spread is hematogenous, these all are involved most commonly.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Osteoporosis – Disc space is well preserved Option: C. Prolapsed IV disc – in this condition, there is prolapse of the disc content outwards Option: D. Secondaries spine – disc space is well-preserved

questions.text: Ideal management for a compression of the cord due to tuberculosis of the spine in a patient on ATT for four months, who is not improving is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ATT + Decompression Anti-tubercular chemotherapy forms the mainstay of treatment. The spine is put to absolute rest by sling traction for the cervical spine and bed rest for the dorsolumbar spine

Severe paraplegia with rapid onset may indicate severe pressure from a mechanical accident or abscess. 4. Any severe paraplegia such as paraplegia in flexion, motor or sensory loss for more than six months, complete loss of motor power for one month despite adequate conservative treatment.
